page.title: 04THE SOUTH DOWNS WAY
page.content: This is a long-distance footpath of 80 miles established in 1972 by the Countryside Commission and goes from Beachy Head to Buriton in Hampshire. This was the main route across Sussex in prehistoric times and it is a well used bridle path with 360 degree views. The remains of a Bronze Age trackway, a cross dyke, goes south to Seaford and a small section is still visible near Hobbs Hawth and forms part of the existing footpath. It was embanked to prevent cattle straying, and in the existing boundary hedge are several granite posts about 2ft. high with the letter 'P' incised. These were boundary stones to mark Pinchem Farm, which is on the first Ordnance Survey Map of 1873. This farm is now called Rathfinny. Hang-gliders use the South Downs Way as a suitable place to practise their sport.
